Authors:
Gavin Craig Hunter, Isabel Zeil-Rolfe, Mireille Jourdan,
Louise Morin
Title:
Venturia euphorbiae comb. nov., a damaging pathogen of
Euphorbia paralias: taxonomic clarification, infection process and host
range
Abstract:
In 2008, a fungal pathogen causing severe necrotic leaf
and stem lesions on Euphorbia paralias in France was isolated and
morphologically identified as Passalora euphorbiae. This fungus offers
potential as a possible biological control agent against E. paralias in
Australia where the plant is invasive. Due to recent taxonomic changes
in the Mycosphaerellaceae including Passalora sensu lato, this study
first sought to confirm the taxonomic position of P. euphorbiae.
Phylogenetic analyses of DNA sequence data from the LSU, ITS and EF-1α
gene regions indicated that the fungus does not group in the
Mycosphaerellaceae and is instead better accommodated in the
Venturiaceae within the genus Venturia. The infection process of the
fungus was examined microscopically and proved similar to that observed
for other Venturia species, corroborating the phylogenetic placement.
Experiments were performed to explore the fungus host range within the
Euphorbia genus and results revealed that the fungus is highly specific,
only infecting E. paralias and its most phylogenetically related
species, E. segetalis. Our study supports the combination of this taxon
into Venturia as Venturia euphorbiae.
